Join the Sacred Hoop American Indian Program of School District 197 and welcome guest speaker Angela Waupochick (pictured) and her presentation on the American Indian connection and understanding of wetlands. The presentation will be on Zoom on Thursday, September 3 at 6:30-7:30 p.m.

Angela Waupochick is currently a PhD student studying Forestry at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. Her research is focused on Black Ash hydrology and management. She previously served as a natural resources manager focusing on water quality and wetland restoration. She is the 2019 National Wetlands Awards recipient for State, Tribal and Local Program Development. post_text: Moreland Arts and Health Sciences Magnet School is the recipient of a $5,000 grant from the National Parent Teacher Association. The grant, sponsored by TikTok, will be used to gather feedback from families that will be used to design and create a weekend backpack food program for students. Food security has been identified as an important need at Moreland. Chanda Parkinson, a Moreland parent and the grant writer, has made it her mission to explore ways to help with food security during her tenure as president of the Moreland PTA. "I am absolutely thrilled that we were able to receive this grant," said Chanda Parkinson. "Families have enough to deal with during this pandemic. If children can come home with food for the weekend, it's one less thing they have to worry about."

Eric Friberg, a science teacher at Henry Sibley High School, has been named a recipient of the Presidential Awards for Excellence in Mathematics and Science Teaching (PAEMST). PAEMST is the highest recognition that a kindergarten through 12th grade science, technology, engineering, mathematics, and/or computer science teacher may receive for outstanding teaching.

"We are extremely proud of Eric," said Henry Sibley Principal Ron Monson. "He is a Henry Sibley alum who has vigorously followed his passion to serve students at his alma mater. He relentlessly pursues students to fully engage them and support their efforts as learners. He fosters a great learning environment through great relationships, deep content knowledge, and high expertise in instructional practices. He is part of a vibrant 'Team Science' that engages in making learning relevant, rigorous, and accessible to ALL of our learners. Students thrive in Eric's learning environment!" #WarriorPride

post_text: Over the course of January, twenty-two students in grades 1st-4th worked to design and build their own a Little Free Library. The idea originated from the group brainstorming how they could incorporate the Pilot Knob STEM Magnet School slogan, 'Do great work and read, read, read,' into an outdoor learning area of the school property. Students researched other free libraries, then designed their own. The final design was developed by combining students' ideas. Students then practiced their measuring skills to help draw blueprints, build a small model, and prepare the materials for the final product. They then used tools to cut, build/assemble, and paint the little free library. The final product will be installed on the school's property this summer after the parking lot construction is completed.

post_text: Students at Friendly Hills Middle School conducted a schoolwide food collection to benefit Neighbors Inc., a local non-profit, social-service agency that provides emergency assistance and supportive assistance to community members. The 8th grade AVID students who managed the food drive chose Neighbors Inc. as the recipient organization after researching what type of service project they wanted to run as well as which organization should receive the donations. Once the students selected a food drive, under the guidance of ESL teacher and AVID advisor Jennifer Ryan, the students also researched what it means for families when they do not have enough food. "I enjoyed watching the students go through the process of deciding what project to do," says Ryan. "And once they made their decision they were on it!"

He also talked about the importance of doing fire drills at school and at home.

post_text: A group of Henry Sibley High School students enrolled in a youth leadership class are volunteering at Moreland Arts and Health Sciences Magnet School this semester. As part of this class, students are required to do a service learning project. The group of students have chosen to work with Moreland students. While at Moreland, the high schoolers are given sight words, books, math flashcards, or other games/activities to work with students on their math and/or reading skills. This opportunity also provides a chance for students to create positive relationships. Way to go! #warriorpride

post_text: Yesterday, students from Heritage Environmental-STEM Middle School had the honor of listening to Dr. Lydia Villa-Komaroff, an accomplished molecular and cellular biologist who has been an academic laboratory scientist, a university administrator, and a business woman. Dr. Villa-Komaroff taught students about the progression of cell therapy while sharing her personal journey of how she became a scientist. A special thank you to Dr. Villa-Komaroff for inspiring and encouraging our students to pursue their dreams!

post_text: Led by Friendly Hills Middle School sixth grade science teachers Crystal Mielke and Katy Lynch, a group of sixth grade students along with members of the Green Team helped build solar suitcases. The suitcases will be shipped to a refugee school in Kenya, Africa, where they will be used to light their classrooms after sunset. The suitcases take in sunlight and solar panels to recharge their batteries. Way to go, FHMS students!
